classic_summary: Today, collaborations like the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab, which launched eight years ago, are continuing to deliver expertise for the promise of tomorrows AI technology. At the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab, success takes the form of 54 patent disclosures, an excess of 128,000 citations with an h-index of 162, and more than 50 industry-driven use cases. The lab is uniquely positioned to identify the right problems to solve, setting us apart from other entities, says Aude Oliva, lab MIT director and director of strategic industry engagement in the MIT Schwarzman College of Computing. The MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab has had tremendous impact by bringing together a rich set of collaborations between IBM and MITs researchers and students, says Provost Anantha Chandrakasan, who is the labs MIT co-chair and the Vannevar Bush Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. Here, the lab shines, bridging research and deployment. Contributions from lab members like Song Han, associate professor in the MIT Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), and IBM Researchs Chuang Gan help make this possible, through work such as once-for-all and AWQ. The impact of MIT-IBM research on our large language model development efforts cannot be overstated, says Cox. Innovations from the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab help shape these technical directions and influence the strategy we are taking in the market through platforms like watsonx. A significant piece of what makes this research ecosystem thrive is the steady influx of student talent and their contributions through MITs Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program (UROP), MIT EECS 6A Program, and the new MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab Internship Program. Academic-industry collaborations, such as the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab, help drive the breakthroughs that make this possible.
semantic_summary:
Here is a high-quality summary of the text in English:

The MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab has been instrumental in driving advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) research and its applications. The lab's collaborations with IBM and MIT researchers have led to significant breakthroughs, including improved stent placement with AI imaging techniques, shrinking models while maintaining performance, and modeling of interatomic potential for silicate chemistry. The lab's work has also focused on developing more efficient and task-specific models, such as smaller foundation models that yield better performance.

The lab's research portfolio is aligned to use and develop new features, capacities, or products for IBM and real-world applications. The lab's efforts have been recognized by academia-industry collaborations, with contributions from over 128,000 citations and 54 patent disclosures. The lab has also made significant impacts in areas such as healthcare, finance, cybersecurity, and robust planning and decision-making.

The MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab is uniquely positioned to identify the right problems to solve, setting it apart from other entities. The lab's success is due to its ability to bring together a rich set of collaborations between IBM and MIT researchers and students, resulting in breakthroughs that can be applied to real-world problems. The lab's work has also been recognized by Gartner, which predicts that at least 30 generative AI projects will be abandoned after proof of concept by the end of 2025.

The lab's contributions have had a significant impact on the development of efficient and optimized models that can be adapted to specific domains and use cases. The lab's work has also been recognized for its potential to foster useful and efficient intelligence, which is crucial for unlocking the full economic and societal potential of AI.
